title: ‘Worst three words in football’: Cowboys unpack loss to Packers, remain hopeful they can be ‘dangerous’
text:
CLOSE Check out some early NFL game headlines. USA TODAY

ARLINGTON, Texas — Amari Cooper was ready to confess his sin.

The “worst three words in football,” he called them.

He was describing his mindset on Dak Prescott’s first interception, a play-action throw to Cooper down the middle of the field that ricocheted off the Cowboys receiver’s hands before Packers cornerback Jaire Alexander snagged it and returned the pick 37 yards.

Cooper had thought to himself on the play: I got it.

“That’s what I was thinking, and those are the worst three words in football,” Cooper said, eschewing praise for his career-high 226 receiving yards as he lamented the interception he felt he should have caught. “I feel like I had it. It was an easy catch. Took my eyes off it because I was focused on the touchdown and I dropped it, and it created a turnover.”

Dak Prescott to Amari Cooper intercepted by Jaire Alexander, who returns it 37 yards. Green Bay capitalizes.



Packers 7, Cowboys 0pic.twitter.com/ia4EIR571u — Jori Epstein (@JoriEpstein) October 6, 2019

It was the first of three turnovers the Cowboys would surrender in a 34-24 loss to Green Bay at home. It yielded the first of 31 straight points the Packers would score before the Cowboys took a ball home.

The Cowboys had several bright spots in their second-straight week coming up short, from the 563 yards of offense they compiled to a fourth quarter in which they outgained the Packers 146 yards to 14 and 12 first downs to three. But the offense that clicked near game’s end and the defense that silenced Aaron Rodgers and Aaron Jones late failed to make those marks in three quarters that yielded a 31-3 deficit until 2:09 remained in the third.

“It is a reality check,” Cowboys running back Ezekiel Elliott said. “It’s going to be hard to win games in this league if we keep shooting ourselves in the foot.”

More: Cowboys owner Jerry Jones jokes about Jason Garrett's 'abusive language' penalty

More: 32 things we learned from Week 5 of the 2019 NFL season

In the Cowboys' consecutive losses, Prescott has now accounted for five interceptions. The Cowboys run defense, meanwhile, allowed Aaron Jones to rush for four touchdowns — the most to any back in franchise history.

A 21-point comeback in the last 18 minutes of the game — which could have been greater, as a penalty negated Brett Maher’s made 28-yard field goal before he missed from 33 ⁠— left players and management with hope that the strengths that propelled the Cowboys team to 3-0 last month weren’t a fluke.

“That’s my man,” Cowboys owner Jerry Jones thought to himself as Prescott scrambled left for 14 yards, 2:45 to play, the Cowboys trailing by 10. “That’s the competitor in him. … I thought, ‘Boy, you have to kill him to get the competitor out of him.’”

But that approach and the roster's talent aren't enough to win games, Prescott said his team realized as the Packers outplayed them.

“We know we’re a good team, and I’m not taking that away or saying we’re not,” the quarterback said. “I know we’re a really, really good team. And we’re confident in the players we have and confident in what we can do.

“But sometimes, you have to know that it’s the work that gets the wins. It’s not the talent. It’s not the camaraderie. It’s the work.”

More: Sky is suddenly the limit for Packers' offense after breakout win vs. Cowboys

More: Packers' defense brings heat on Cowboys' Ezekeil Elliott, Dak Prescott after focusing on fundamentals

That message permeated throughout a surprisingly steady losing locker room.

Sure, Jones, coaches and players were all disappointed that the performance for most of the game fell short of what they needed to win. But they left the field motivated by their comeback attempt and inspired by teammates’ accountability for the slew of miscues.

Take Cooper honing in on the interception he tipped rather than his receiving output.

“Amari saying that, I think, is an example of guys in the locker room,” Prescott said. “A lot of guys on our team look in the mirror before they point fingers.

“As long as we have those type of guys on our team, we’re going to be fine.”

In all likelihood, reversing their fortunes will take a more consistent performance throughout games. It will take surer tackling with running threats like Le’Veon Bell, Sony Michel and Todd Gurley ahead on the schedule. It will take much better ball security from Prescott, who Jones insisted is “renowned for his ability to protect the ball,” though he added “the turnover thing alone really puts you behind the eight ball.”

But “the best thing for me tonight,” Jones continued, is that “our team didn’t understand right at the end of the game, in the last two minutes, three minutes, that they couldn’t win this game. … We’ve got a spirit that really is encouraging.”

Now the Cowboys must implement that spirit, and those inconsistent bursts of competitiveness, across all four quarters of each game. Before visiting the Jets next week, they’ll look in the mirror to do just that, players said.

“We don’t necessarily have to have our backs against the wall to play like we did [late],” Prescott said. “We’ve got to figure out whatever it is, find out the way or whatever it is to start the game like that.

“When we find that, it’s going to be dangerous.”

Follow Jori Epstein on Twitter @JoriEpstein.

If you love talking football, we have the perfect spot for you. Join our Facebook Group, The Ruling Off the Field, to engage in friendly debate and conversation with fellow football fans and our NFL insiders.
description: The Cowboys fell behind early against the Packers, but they're hoping their resilience is a harbinger for what the team can accomplish.
